Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Identifying Chemistry Laboratory Safety Conceptions: An International Study

POR.DRECONTENT:
The analysis of what misconceptions are occurring with students is of importance from both the safety aspect and from science theory application. Students need to be able to apply scientific theory to laboratory work and be able to interpret science concepts to their own chemical safety considerations. Different countries may teach chemical safety in unique ways, and to develop an overall curriculum teaching students about chemical safety without the creation of alternative conceptions is vital. The impact of this research study was in identifying common misconceptions in Singapore to determine what may be causing students’ misconceptions along with using this data to compare to previous data taken within the United States. This was done to increase the effectiveness of safety training in undergraduate laboratories by decreasing accidents due to student misconceptions. The central objective of the proposed research was to understand what alternate conceptions about chemistry and laboratory safety were prevalent within chemistry laboratory classes. The goal of the questionnaire was to assess the typical student’s misconceptions about safety practices within a chemistry laboratory class. The questionnaire was analyzed by identifying key words and concepts for the given situations posed to the students.

The analysis of what misconceptions were occurring with students was of importance from both the safety aspect and from science theory application. Students need to be able to apply scientific theory to laboratory work and be able to interpret science concepts to their own chemical safety considerations.  The  participation rate was overall 95% of the combined enrollment from each school, with 91% from the Secondary School (72 out of 79 students) and 99% from the Junior College (72 out of 74 students). The schools were chosen based on the types of students and instructor participation. Students were solicited for participation during the end of the semester in the lecture component.

Analysis was carried out by identifying evidence of key words and primary concept knowledge. The established grading rubric was based on a comparison to specific answers provided by chemistry laboratory experts.  The Questionnaire data was verified using student interviews and using inter-rater reliability. Reliability was proven via student interviews and the students responding the same way in interviews two months later as when they took the online Questionnaire. Validity was proven by student interviews asking students whether or not the findings on their Questionnaire answers were similar to what the researcher coded and agreement between the two views was seen as coding verification. The establishment of keywords was verified using inter-rater reliability with experts randomly evaluating a small sample of student questionnaires using the established keyword rubric. The concepts addressed in the Questionnaire dealt with hazard rankings of acids versus bases, mercury spill, gas leak, fume cupboard usage, strong versus weak acids, unknown chemical spill, dilution of a concentrated acid, and definitions of the terms toxic and carcinogenic. Some of the analysis highlights from the study will be discussed further.

On preliminary analysis, students appear to still have difficulties with understanding certain terminology due to previous learning. The common usage of the terms strong and weak in everyday language gives students an incorrect idea about properties of acids and bases. Approximately 78% of the Junior College students and 81% of the Secondary students believed that strong acids would be more hazardous and no students when asked to elaborate upon their choice of strong over weak mentioned anything besides that strong meant powerful or concentrated.
